MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1976 TO 31ST MARCH, 1977



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [6th Allotted Day]

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head V --

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to he allocated for Head v be reduced my $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs L. P. Rodrigo. Hwang Soo Jin. N. Govindasamy. Sia Khoon Seong. Ng Kah Ting. Ho Kah Leong, P. Govindaswamy and Ch'ng Jit Koon.)

    No ministry in our Government has been as riddled with problems as the Ministry of Education. Only last year one of the previous

Column: 818

Ministers for Education came out with a restructured system which he claimed was not an exercise on paper. A warning was sounded in the House that what seemed to have started with a bang might end with a whimper and actually this seems to have come to pass, because new directions have this year been laid down. How is ii that all these things have happened in education?

    The basic education policy of the Government was laid down in the chapter Spring Source of our Nation, incorporated in the Party manifesto The Tasks Ahead, in 1959. I agree with the previous Minister, who is now the Minister for Science and Technology, that basically this policy has not changed. Throughout the years of PAP rule. this policy has been assiduously adhered to because it was shown to have continuous relevance and to be grounded in a clear-sighted understanding of issues.

Column: 819



    So we have trained teachers and built schools to give everybody a place and a chance for primary education. We have given places in secondary school to all who have qualified for it. We have established the Institute of Education to provide for more varied and better quality of training of teachers; although here presently a constituent has written to me commenting upon the alarmingly small output of teachers from the Institute of Education. We have established the Industrial Training Board in response to an important article in our education policy, namely, that of contributing towards a better and more productive economy. We have done our best to take care of the material aspects of our policy with emphasis on science and technology. technical training, a chance for everybody to prepare himself for a job for which he may be well fitted. We have encouraged bilingualism and multi-lingualism in response also to the needs for integration in a multi-racial community.

    These lines of policy direction are as relevant today as they were in 1959. Yet we seem to have missed out on some important ingredient. I am not talking about the changes which have been many indeed: for example, we have had three or four Ministers of Education within the space of less than 1 5 months - a high turnover rate indeed. Changing directives have been freely issued but these switches, modifications and variations are not basically the ailment, they seem to me to be symptoms. They indicate that we have been more concerned with the educational outcomes that we wanted or thought we could contrive. The point is we were so concerned with objects and objectives that we lost sight of the fact that we were dealing with children and people. Let us just consider the following scenario relating to the early education of our children.

    At a pre-school stage our children are brought up in an atmosphere of care and attention. Parents show their great affection for their children by looking after them well, and even by indulging them. Our children respond with a freshness. We can see it in

Column: 820

the kindergarten classes in the community centres when we organize little occasions for children. They respond with a freshness. That, however, seems to be a little dimmed when they enter into school. Once our children go to school they become enmeshed, geared into a system that is heavily influenced by a compulsion to achieve, initially in a superficial way, namely, the examination. Towards the aim of passing examinations, pupils will obediently lap up even a surfeit of information (I think our school curricula are over-loaded), and regurgitate what is appropriate for examination purposes.

    Generally our children give the appearance of being obedient and well disciplined. Or is it that they are subservient and subordinate to the petty needs to achieve in examination. Of course, many do not achieve. The normal distribution of talent would exclude them from the meritocratic upper strata.

    Emphasis on competition has resulted in the inculcation of some very good virtues -for example, a willingness to work hard and to strive after set objectives. But because of the need to achieve distinction in schools, teachers too have been tempted to Orientate their teaching simply to those factors that are tested and are revealed by examinations. In the process a fundamental educational principle is ignored. The system becomes subject-oriented, not pupil-oriented. The basic principle that you learn when you are at the Teachers' Training College or normal classes or at the Institute of Education is that you care for the little children. You orientate your effort towards the children, not towards what you want to teach them. They are not bottles into which you fill little things. It is no wonder that we have discovered in dismay lapses into illiteracy in fact possibility that literacy may never have been achieved by some who have gone through the primary stages of our school system.

    The system has significant characteristics of being an impersonal one. Even in the treatment of teachers, much has been said time and again about the impersonality of directives and poor communication between

Column: 821

the Ministry and the people in the field. This impersonality can be further illustrated by the way a very senior Ministry official, in addressing school principals, likened a school to a factory, principals to managers, and pupils to factory products. With that kind of attitude characterising the thinking of a very senior man, what sort of human component do you expect to be worked in to the attitude towards children?

    This sort of attitude has led to the notion that the school can provide the inputs that will result in a pupil endowed with the right knowledge and attitudes. We have not thought too often about the fact that the child's environment also determines the way he behaves. We have changed the physical environment for thousands of our children as a result of our successes in the housing field. But is it not possible for us to try, through the mass media especially, to reach to the home and community environment, to the parents and adult citizens, to show them how they might reinforce what we teach our children in schools.

    However, even what we teach our children in schools in respect of their cultural, historical, geographical environment becomes subordinate to other considerations as, for example, Education for Living having to be in the second language. Education for Living should be taught by Education-for-Living teachers, not by second language teachers. Frequently the two specialisms do not coincide.

    In the end, where community influence and school influence have combined to sharpen the competitive instinct in our young people, we get what is exemplified in the following. When a team wins a school debate on television, the members of the winning team are so completely overcome with elation that they have no care for how their opponents feel as a result of their unseemly jubilation. When results are announced at an interschool band competition at the National Stadium, the same unseemly jubilation results in near chaos on the field. Ranks are broken, nearly all semblance of order and

Column: 822

discipline become vapourised. Where is the spirit of the game? Where is the vying in friendly competition? Where is the consideration of one young person for another in these hysterical circumstances? All this is the result of the emphasis not on individuality but on individualism.

    And talking of individuality, let me hark back to the odious comparison of the school to the factory. It is important that all should realise that the child at whatever stage he leaves school is never a finished product. He is a developing person. You cannot produce finished products from schools. The child is a developing person, moving to the next stage of his life, growing, changing with a personality blossoming and in some sad cases withering. I do not think our teachers are interested in producing stereotyped finished products, duly labelled and set out on the assembly line. On the whole, I think our teachers are concerned for their charges, that is why they find all the administrative and clerical work that is sometimes imposed upon them irksome.

    I think we want to give our teachers all the support possible in the development of individuality in our young citizens, and we want, if possible, to encourage schools to bear the stamp and impress of each school's particular personality.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the outset I wish to stress that the observations which I will make under this head are made with the knowledge that the Minister of State has a difficult job on his hands. But at the same time I want to say that he must grasp in perspective the problems that have bedevilled the Ministry, and in this regard I will make references to specific issues which I have raised in this House. In doing so, I also wish to indicate to the Minister the existence in his Ministry of a professional mechanism which appears to obscure fundamental errors of decision in education policy or implementation of policy. I would warn the Minister of the propensities of this mechanism and to ask him to be alert in issues of education at all times.

    If there is one Ministry the successes or failures of which determine the successes or

Column: 823

failures in other Ministries and ultimately in the performance of the nation, it is the Ministry of Education. Education makes the kind of manpower which will fill the Ministries and which man the nation. It determines the kind of young people you have, the workers, the soldiers, the managers, the leadership you have; and then it also determines the kind of teachers you have. And if these teachers are 30% below par, then their pupils will probably be 30%-plus below par; and if some of these pupils themselves become teachers then these teachers will probably be 3O%-plus-3O% below par, and so on. Finally teachers will not be able to give much of value to the pupils because they have not got the stuff themselves. On this, I said in 1968 Hansard, Vol. 28, col. 364):

    `The reason why I am concerned with the subject of education is my belief that it will take a new society, a society with radically different responses and reactions, if we are to achieve national security and prosperity in the years ahead. And in the final analysis, it is the content of the education that we provide our young today which will determine their responses and reactions tomorrow.'

    Today we have improvements of the recently restructured system. The recently restructured system was a restructure of the system restructured in 1968. At that time I said [Hansard, Vol. 28, col. 365]:

    But today we have restructured our education system. The restructuring is extensive in scope, involving primary, secondary, technical, tertiary and teacher education which I hope is a final restructuring, and is intended to describe in perspective our education system.'

2.45 p.m.

    I was a little optimistic.

    Today we have identified certain basic difficulties in our system, one of which is the non-retention policy by which pupils get promoted upwards irrespective of their performance in the year. This difficulty, we all seem to agree, is partly responsible for the slide into illiteracy. But the Backbench identified it in 1968. In the debate on the President's speech in May that year I said, after analysing the defects of the non-retention policy [Hansard. Vol. 27, col. 89]:

Column: 824



    `The non-retention policy by which the student of maximum age for that class is promoted to the next grade at the end of the year, despite his failure in the terminal examinations, progressively worsens his inarticulateness apart from his overall ability. Sir, this is a decline which must be arrested immediately.'

    Even at this time I was already aghast at the kind of effects that the non-retention policy was producing. The non-retention policy was introduced in 1956 by the Ministry of Education to correct the inability of the administration at that time to build schools sufficiently fast enough to accommodate a backlog of children due to commence schooling.

    Today the Ministry has also discovered the meaninglessness of the Primary School Leaving Examination and has initiated the assessment system at the end of six years' primary education. This is also done at the end of the third year of primary education as described in the restructured system. This is intended to divert pupils at an early stage so that they will be able to learn at their own rate of capacity. In the debate in 1968 after underlining the adverse effects that the Primary School Leaving Examination was having on our primary and secondary education I said [Hansard, Vol. 27, col. 89]:

    `Sir, as suggested, the Primary School Leaving Examination may be suitably modified or even abolished and in its place a system of annual assessment set up.'

    I also said in that debate [Hansard. Vol. 27, cols. 87-8]:

    `Sir, diversion of academic potential, which is the end product of six years primary education, to technical education and vocational training is short of what is ideally correct. Diversion of primary school students to vocational training as it is being done today must cease. It is a diversion of primary school students who have failed in the Primary School Leaving Examination. notoriously, abbreviated as PSLE, and who are over-aged. It operates on the inscrutable theory that the overage rejects of this examination have an aptitude for vocational training. I would suggest that the Government consider making the diversion at the early secondary school sta9e.'

    The Chairman: Mr Rodrigo, could you slow down a bit because the interpreters cannot catch up with what you are saying.

    Mr Rodrigo: Sir, I am trying to hurry between the interpreters and your ten- minute guillotine.

Column: 825



    The Chairman: That is too bad. You are so long-winded.

    Mr Rodrigo: In this case the Ministry did rearrange the diversion to take place at the end of Secondary II in 1969. But I am sure it was not as a result of my having raised it. Suffice it to say that my anxieties have been confirmed by the initiative of the Ministry.

    I have made these flashbacks with the intention of indicating to the Minister that on education the Backbench has searched the subject and articulated on it extensively in Parliament. Contributions have come from the Members for Jurong. Paya Lebar. Jalan Kayu and Telok Blangah. I hesitate to include the Member for Moulmein. I think he holds a watching brief for teachers in this House. If I have omitted quoting all Members it is purely because of a lack of time.

    We are realising today that the traditional media in which the education of pupils is undertaken, i.e, the classroom, has lost its effectiveness as the form at the primary level. The classroom has always been a grouping in which there quickly developed a relationship between teacher and pupils that made education possible and effective. This form dissipated as soon as subject teaching was liberally used in the primary schools. If four subjects in the class time-table draw into the classroom four different teachers of the subjects, then the close intimate relationship between one teacher and 35 pupils is lost and in its place there is only the indifferent communication link between one teacher and 140 pupils. What happens then is that you no longer tend to have education but instruction and therefore you no longer have schools but centres of instruction. Subject teaching may be suitable as a method of instruction, but is it suitable as a form of education? I expressed this worry in 1968 where I insisted that quality in education can be achieved only when the classroom retains the intimacy of the teacher-pupil relationship. I would urge the Minister to explore the desirability of once again recovering what we formerly had, that is, the true form teacher.

    But let me say that our education system has not collapsed. There are major defects. If

Column: 826

we are to attempt the correction of these defects we must be realistic. These defects cannot be solely attributed to the system. The failure in or the non-performance of teachers has helped to bring about these defects. The bull in the china shop is all right. Sir, but teachers are not china wares also. If I am the Backbencher to say these unpopular things, let it be so. But to what extent the system has been responsible in stifling the performance of teachers so that their performance as the teacher has been aborted or retarded by the system, is a matter for the Minister to find out and correct.

    Here, I wish to make the point that the Ministry in charge of half a million pupils and the teacher unions representing approximately 20,000 teachers determine much of the future of our society. While I realise that parents in their homes owe it to themselves and their children to begin laying the basis for the development of character and ability, many parents still depend and, in fact, expect the institution of the school to nurture their children into citizens useful to parents and society. This in itself calls for a re-education of parents. In this co'inection, what does the Minister think about reactivating on a mass scale parent-teacher association?

    Teacher unions have grave responsibilities in the effort to make our education, system successful. On the question of education policies and their implementation, teacher unions cannot afford to posturise or compromise to achieve administrative convenience at the risk of a deterioration in the content of education. Principals of primary schools had their post allowances withdrawn. This change removed administrative difficulties in selecting senior teachers as principals of primary schools At the same time, the professionals in the Ministry are prepared to admit that the system should assist in achieving the correct motivated principal for the school in order that the entire school functions. If the restoration of post allowances for such principals is necessary I would urge the Minister to do so.

Column: 827



    The Chairman: Mr Rodrigo, your time is up.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, travelling in an elevator one day recently, I happened to overhear a conversation between two school children. They were arguing as to who was the Minister for Education. Neither of them was obviously in the right and they would appear to realise it too, as they finally compromised by agreeing that what difference did it make whether it was Lee, Chua or Chai.

    Sir, this little incident, amusing as it may be, illustrates very well the state of confusion we are all in as a result of regular changes in our education policy in recent years from Ministry officers to school principals, teachers, pupils and parents. It would seem to me that very few people really know what is happening at any one moment. Take, for example the subject of the use of the School Funds. More than a year ago, the attention of the Public Accounts Committee of Parliament was drawn to the fact that all the schools in Singapore had among them accumulated a total sum of close to $10 million under their School Funds and this large sum of money was left lying idle in banks. The reason, as the Committee discovered, was apparently that principals were at a loss as to how to go about obtaining the necessary approval from the Ministry to use their School Funds.

    The Public Accounts Committee of Parliament, under the chairmanship of the Hon. Member for Katong, then recommended that the money should be used for the purposes intended, since they were collected from the pupils. Subsequently, in March 1975, a Notification No. 73 was issued by the Ministry authorising the principals to incur any expenditure not exceeding $200 from their School Funds. This partial relaxation obviously was not too successful as on 1 7th December, 1975 a further Notification No. 150 on the same subject was issued, removing all restrictions in the use of School Funds. On the one hand, this news was enthusiastically welcomed by the teaching

Column: 828

profession and hailed as a significant step taken in the right direction, and yet in an article entitled "School Funds, a New Look", appearing in the latest issue of the Teachers Rostrum, the author urged that principals would appreciate it very much if some guidelines could be provided for them. This, to my mind, suggests that principals are still at a loss as to how they should go about using their newly delegated authority.

    Incidentally, Sir, you would have noted that the first Notification No. 73, referred to by me earlier, was issued in March 1975 but by December 1975 the second notification on the same subject has already reached the number 150. In other words, altogether a total number of 78 notifications were issued by the Ministry to schools in a matter of nine months. I do not know what is contained in the other 76 notifications. All that I can say is that I sympathise with the poor principals and teachers in trying to comply with whatever the nature of the numerous notifications, not to mention the poor pupils who obviously suffer in the process.

    A more recent example is to be found in a seminar conducted by the Ministry. According to the press, at the opening of the Seminar the Senior Minister of State emphasised the need to educate school children on population control. There were, I gather, subsequent speakers from the Ministry. After listening to the various speeches, some primary school principals, I was told, went away from the seminar feeling rather confused as to what they were expected to do. One expressed rather grave concern to me that principals were asked to borrow films and illustrations from the Family Planning and Population Board to show to their children. His interpretation was that primary school children were to be taught sex education or birth control.

    These two examples only serve to illustrate a rather sorry state of affairs in the implementation of our education policy. It would seem to me that a very serious communication gap exists in all levels of our Ministry and the schools. The gap would appear to be much worse between the Ministry and the schools. Sir, unless there is

Column: 829

greater and constant awareness of the need, on the part of those implementing the policies of Government, for proper dialogue to be maintained between Ministry officers and the schools, policy decisions are unlikely to be correctly interpreted and translated into suitable administrative actions to attain the desired objectives. We have emphasised on greater qualitative improvement in our education system but until and unless the very fundamental problem of communication gap can he satisfactorily resolved. I have my doubts as to the extent of improvement that we can hope to achieve.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, since 1959 our education policy has undergone many and varied changes. Two features stand out for commendation and condemnation. Let us take the commendable feature first. We have diversified the educational structure from a purely academic type of education given to pupils in the past to one with a science and technology bias. Our emphasis on technical schools. vocational institutes, etc, is a complimentable feature. Other than that, we have left a string of failures.

    Our education policy is still examination-oriented. Let us take the Primary School Leaving Examination first, the six to seven-year primary education controversy. What happens to the thousands of children who have failed the Primary School Leaving Examination? About 10 or 12 years ago, we started post-primary classes for Primary VI failures and advocated the setting lip of post-primary vocational classes for pupils who did not make the grade for a regular secondary education. The Ministry of Education was not prepared nor equipped for the vocational classes and the programme was a failure and the post primary vocational classes closed down.

3.00 p.m.

    Now we are talking in terms of allowing pupils who failed the PSLE to repeat and to keep them in schools until they are 1 5 years

Column: 830

old. What kind of instruction are the 1 5-year old backward pupils going to get? I should not have called them "backward pupils". In the new educational parlance, they are ESN, Educationally Sub-Normal. Are they going to be grouped with the other students who have failed? Are there still going to be 40-odd backward overaged pupils in the same class? Does the Ministry seriously expect the 1 5-year olds who fail year after year to really make good with 40 such pupils in any one class? What attention is going to be paid to them to actually make them useful citizens? Are remedial teaching methods advocated? If so, has any thought been given to remedial education, and are answers available? These are questions for which answers must be found before action could be initiated.

    Let us take our second language policy. From normal second language teaching, the Ministry of Education advocated additional exposure for the second language. When they found that the children were not effectively bilingual, they decided they could solve the problem by increased exposure to second language for all. Subjects normally taught in the first language had to be :aught in the second language. As a result, we found that many of our pupils who were not effective in the second language earlier became ineffective in both the first as well as the second languages. What we are now, therefore, advocating is back to square one, and that is, an under-exposure for those who are not able to cope up with the two languages.

    We gave another name for Civics. We did away with History and introduced Education for Living to be taught in the second language. This has really become neither a civics lesson, nor an Education for Living lesson but in many schools, it has bec3me a second language lesson. Again, a failure.

    Activity method advocated by one of the seven Education Ministers (we have had seven Ministers since 1959) became PPP. For those who are uninitiated in the educational jargon of these days, it means the Primary Pilot Project.

Column: 831



    An Hon. Member: Play, play, play!

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Yes. A big boo-ha was made. Special classes for teachers were conducted. Special teaching aids were made. Instruction manuals were printed. Thousands of dollars were spent by individual teachers as well as schools. After a few years' trial, even as late as last year, we were told that the PPP programme has come to stay. Now I hear it is out. Why?

    Only last year we were debating in this Chamber on another new education policy, namely the Restructured Education System. There were considerable criticisms as well as apprehension about this policy. The Education Minister then, tried to explain the system, not too successfully, I am afraid. He also sang praises for such a system. Sir, now the rumour has it that the Restructured Education System is still-born.

    Every child was forced to participate in extra-curricular activities. Special record cards were introduced for ECA. The points system was introduced. Parents kicked up a row. Members of Parliament made speeches in this House and ECA cards were withdrawn and insistence on participation in ECA has been relaxed and forgotten. Another change in policy or a failure?

    Our teachers, while keeping tab of the numerous changes and trying to understand and implement them, have also to be Anti-Narcotics Counsellors and, of late, as has been mentioned earlier by the Member for Jalan Kayu, family planning experts.

    An Hon. Member: Post Office Savings Bank.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Yes, Post Office Savings Bank. I read in the papers that family planning or population education is to be given even in primary schools. Do we seriously expect primary school students to understand family planning concept?

    The shortage of teachers in our schools is phenomenal, especially graduate teachers in secondary schools. Even from the Government's own statistics, in Division I alone, there is a vacancy position of 45.3%.

Column: 832

Secondary school pupils even up to Secondary IV levels are being taught by non-graduate teachers, in some cases, even by those who themselves only have a School Certificate. The Ministry of Education ought to be grateful to these teachers who teach Secondary IV classes far beyond their call of duty. There was some talk earlier on of upgrading these teachers by inservice classes in the Institute of Education. What has happened to this scheme? How does the Ministry hope to recruit graduates for secondary schools?

    Ordinary teachers, principals and inspectors have now been classified differently. Just as a jaga these days calls himself a Security Officer, and a door-to-door salesman calls himself a Sales Representative, our teachers, principals, inspectors, etc, have become EOs, SEOs, PEOs, EDOs, ADs and DDs. Very soon we may run out of alphabets! This euphemism has become some kind of a status symbol among our educators. The need for promotion prospects for teachers was understandable. In fact, I was one of those who advocated for more promotion posts in our Education Service but never did I dream that the Ministry would be creating so many grades of teachers. It appears as if there are no more teachers in our Education Service.

    Are all the failures that I have enumerated necessary? Sir, a study of the Hansard, as pointed out by the Hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens, would show that numerous criticisms were made in this Chamber. Some of the pitfalls of the education policies were pointed out and they could have been avoided. If only the gods at Kay Siang Road had genuinely discussed with the organisations representing the teachers and the people who have to implement the policy before proposing any new scheme, many pitfalls could have been avoided. When I say "discussions and consultations". I mean genuine discussions and consultations and not some little dictator from the Ministry of Education calling up principals and organisations representing teachers and giving them a lecture on the latest policies.

    Is there a moral to be learnt from the past failures? I would say `yes.
